Name: Containers
Description: The Containers hierarchy contains terms for objects used to hold substances or other objects. Included are terms for containers intended for culinary use, for horticultural use, for health care, hygiene, and similar personal needs as well as terms for containers associated with liturgical, funerary, and other ceremonial activities.

Name: Backpack
Description: Container of personal equiptment worn on the back by means of a strap over each shoulder.

Name: Bag
Description: Containers or receptacles of leather, cloth, paper, or other flexible material, often capable of being closed at the mouth. For ladies' bags intended to carry personal articles, use "bags (costume accessories).

Name: Basket
Description: Containers made of twigs, rushes, thin strips of wood, or other flexible material woven together.

Name: Purse
Description: Small to medium-sized receptacles made of leather or other flexible material and frequently having several inner compartments, used for carrying money and other personal items, fastened with a zipper, clasp, press stud, etc., and carried as a ladies' handbag or shoulderbag.

Name: Letter Holder
Description: Containers specifically used for written information in document form.

Name: Magazine Rack
Description: Racks for storing and/or displaying magazines.

Name: Storage Container
Description: General term for containers that store materials.

Name: Pillboxes
Description: Boxes, usually shallow and often round, for holding pills.

Name: Waste Basket
Description: Standing baskets or basketlike containers for wastepaper and small items of trash.

Name: Storage Bin or Box
Description: Boxes, usually of medium to large size, intended for the storage of linens, clothing, books, food, artifacts, or any other item. They are usually lidded or have flaps that allow the box to be closed. They may be made of cardboard, wood, metal, plastic, wicker, or another material.

Name: Furniture
Description: Movable or fixed objects or equipment, which may be either functional or ornamental, particularly objects for sitting, reclining, or storage, such as chairs, beds, tables, cabinets, etc., in a dwelling, business, or public space.

Name: Case Furniture
Description: Furniture that encloses a space and is generally boxlike in structure; intended for storage or display.

Name: Bookshelf
Description: Open shelves for holding books; distinct from "bookcases" which generally have several shelves enclosed by doors.

Name: File Cabinet
Description: Cabinets with drawers sized to hold documents; often, but not always, made of metal.

Name: Dresser
Description: Refers to low chests of drawers often surmounted by a mirror and typically used in a bedroom or dressing room as a surface for grooming and to store clothing and toiletries. The term in this context is used primarily in America, and is derived from the European "dresser (cupboard)," which contains drawers and is surmounted by shelves, but is used to store kitchen utensils and dishes.

Name: Dresser Drawers
Description: Chests with one or two tiers of drawers below a deep storage space; precursor to chests of drawers. Use "chests of drawers" for case furniture having two or more drawers but lacking a deep storage space.

Name: Dresser Top
Description: Chests of drawers having a full-length mirror on one side and drawers on the other.

Name: Nightstand
Description: Small tables made to stand beside a bed; includes those having a cupboard to hold a chamber pot and those with a close stool that pulls forward in the lower part.

Name: Support Furniture
Description: Furniture used to hold or support other materials.

Name: Table
Description: Articles of furniture consisting of a flat, slablike top supported on one or more legs or supports.

Name: Coffee Table
Description: Occasional tables, often placed in front of a sofa in a living room. A coffee table is relatively low, of a convenient height for access while seated at the sofa. It is used for serving coffee, tea, cocktails, displaying large books or magazines, or various other purposes.

Name: Desk
Description: Various forms of furniture for readers or writers, generally having a flat writing surface and often drawers and other compartments.

Name: Dining Table
Description: Tables designed for and used while eating meals in a dining room. Distinguished from kitchen tables, which are intended for less formal meals in a kitchen.

Name: End Table (Vanity)
Description: Any small tables used in relation to a couch or chair.

Name: TV Tray
Description: Meal trays of a size and designed to fit across the lap of a person sitting in bed; often fitted with legs or supports at each end.

Name: Library Table
Description: Oblong tables of sturdy construction for use in libraries both public and private for the inspection of books or other materials.

Name: Seating Furniture
Description: No Description

Name: Sofa/Couch
Description: Long, upholstered seating objects with a back and two ends, and primarily used for sitting rather than reclining. Distinct from "couches (reclining furniture)" which have a back support and one end and are primarily used for reclining rather than sitting. The term "sofa" was first used in France at the end of the 17th century as an alternative for canap√©. The terms sofa and settee are virtually interchangeable in 20th-century usage but there is a distinction between the two; a sofa is generally completely upholstered.

Name: Chair
Description: Seats for one person with a back or a back and arms. Distinct from "stools" which have no back.

Name: Other Furniture
Description: Furnishings and Equipment

Name: Mirror
Description: Objects with a highly polished surface, designed to reflect images clearly. The surface is typically smooth, flat, or sometimes slightly curved, made of polished metal in ancient and medieval times, but later usually of glass with a reflective coating on one side.

Name: Storage Spaces
Description: Rooms or areas in a structure that are allocated for storage.

Name: Closet
Description: Small side-rooms or recesses in a structure, usually having a door, built or used for storing clothing, utensils, or provisions.

Name: Closet inside
Description: Small rooms, usually in a home, built or used for storing clothing.

Name: Cabinets
Description: Relatively small, private rooms, often adjacent to bedrooms in great houses, serving as sitting rooms, rooms for dressing, study, devotion, or private meetings, and, during certain periods, often containing collections of curiosities and art objects.

Name: Counter
Description: Flat working surfaces on top of waist-level cabinets, such as found near or adjacent to the sinks in kitchens and bathrooms.

Name: Drawers
Description: Sliding receptacles, fitted into furniture, that can be drawn out horizontally.

Name: Steps
Description: Pieces of furniture consisting of risers and treads, typically used indoors in place of ladders.

Name: Architectural Elements
Description: Forms, structural or decorative, developed originally or primarily as components of architecture, often adapted to other habitable spaces, such as in large vehicles, and often borrowed or imitated for structural or decorative use on other objects.

Name: Door
Description: Barriers that swing, slide, tilt, or fold to close a doorway, usually of solid and finished construction and usually leading to or separating interior spaces. Use also for similar features that close a container or a piece of case furniture. For barriers of less solid or finished construction, and usually separating two exterior spaces, use "gates."

Name: Light Switch
Description: Mechanisms for making, breaking, or changing connections in electrical circuits.

Name: Toilet
Description: Plumbing fixtures consisting typically of a water-flushed bowl with a toilet seat.

Name: Toilet Tank Top
Description: Sets of vessels and other articles intended for use on a toilet or dressing table; generally including a variety of small boxes and bottles, and sometimes also a brush, comb, mirror, or tray. In modern usage, such sets are more common for women's toilets than for men's.

Name: Shelves
Description: Boards, planks, or slabs of wood or any other rigid material fixed in a horizontal position to a wall or in a case, to hold books or other objects as in a bookcase or cabinet.

Name: Floor
Description: The surfaces of rooms or spaces on which one walks.

Name: Information Form
Description: he Information Forms hierarchy contains terms for textual, graphic, and physical objects having the primary and original purpose to record or convey specific information.

Name: Information Artifact
Description: Physical formats, objects, digital information, or other non-material human constructs by which specific information may be recorded or conveyed. For example, books, leaflets, or audiotapes; or in computing, the primary components of an information artifct are information systems and procedures related to the artifact.

Name: Calendar
Description: Registers of days or other contrivances for reckoning days, months, years, etc., such as a table showing the division of a given year into its months, weeks, days, years, or other divisions of time. A calendar may include important astronomical data, ecclesiastical or other festivals, and other events belonging to specific days. For calendric systems of dates, see children under "<dates by calendars>."

Name: Refrigerator Artifact
Description: Rocks, material, or objects that produces a magnetic field external to itself, which causes the magnet to attract other ferromagnetic materials, such as iron, and attracts or repels other magnets.

Name: Magazine, Book, Publication, Document
Description: Documents distributed to the public by sale or other transfer of ownership, or by rental, lease, or lending.

Name: Reminder Card
Description: Rectangular pieces of stiff paper or plastic, usually of standard dimensions, used as a support on which information is typed, written, or transcribed.

Name: Picture Frame
Description: Framing for two-dimensional visual works; picture frames may or many not use glass to protect the work, depending upon the type of work framed.

Name: Scale
Description: Household accessories, usually portable, meant for persons to stand on in order to ascertain their weight.

Name: Timepieces
Description: Devices for measuring and recording the passage of time.

Name: Clock Radio
Description: Clocks with a bell or buzzer that can be set to sound at a particular time, as to awaken someone.

Name: Clock
Description: Refers to instruments that measure and indicate the passage of time, especially by mechanical means producing a regularly recurring action and indicating, usually by hands or changing numbers, the hours and minutes; not designed to be worn or otherwise carried about on a person. For wearable timepieces, see "watches."

Name: Equipment
Description: Articles or physical resources used to array, dress up, rig out, equip, or otherwise provide with what is requisite for efficient action by a person or animal or for a thing.

Name: Computer Equipment
Description: Describes the physical parts or components of a computer.

Name: Computer
Description: Electronic devices or systems capable of automatically performing prescribed sequences of operations on digitised data to achieve a desired end result.

Name: Laptop
Description: Microcomputers so compact that they can be operated while resting on the user's lap.

Name: Tablet
Description: Computers intermediate in size between a laptop and a smartphone that use a touch-activated screen.

Name: Smartphone
Description: Portable, cordless telephones for use in a cellular radio network.

Name: Printer
Description: Output devices that convert coded information from the processor into a readable form on paper.

Name: Keyboard
Description: Assemblages of systematically arranged keys by which a machine is operated.

Name: Appliances
Description: Devices used in a domestic context that facilitate such tasks as food preparation, food storage, cleaning, and grooming and that are powered by fuel or electricity.

Name: Refrigerator
Description: Containers or spaces maintained at a low temperature by means of ice or mechanical apparatus for the purpose of preserving its contents, especially food or drink.

Name: Stove
Description: Portable or fixed apparatuses that furnish heat for warmth or cooking, commonly using coal, oil, gas, wood, or electricity as a source of power.

Name: Water Dispenser
Description: Vessels for holding drinking water that is cooled and drawn off by a faucet or spigot.

Name: Coffee Maker
Description: Generally refers to any of various utensils in which coffee is infused, brewed, percolated, or boiled. Specifically, it usually refers to an electrical appliance for making coffee that may be run automatically.

Name: TV and Remote
Description: elecommunication system whereby visual images, with or without accompanying sound, are converted to electromagnetic waves and transmitted to distant receivers where they are reconverted into moving visual images.

Name: Telecommunication
Description: Systems for communicating at a distance, often a collection of individual communications networks, transmission systems, relay stations, subsidiary stations, data terminal equipment, and other facilities for disseminating information. Examples include telephone, telegraph, radio, television, optical communications, internet, etc.

Name: Telephone
Description: Instruments, apparatus, or devices that convey or reproduce sounds at a distance, especially such devices in which the human voice is transmitted as by wire, satellite, or via base-station antennas as short-wave analog or digital signals. The term was used as early as the 18th century to refer to string phones (cups joined by a string), but the modern device is attributed to Alexander Graham Bell, who patented it in March 1876. That original telephones worked on the principle that sounds of speech are complex vibrations in air, which can be transferrable to solid bodies and in electrical impulses in conducting metals.

Name: Radio
Description: Telecommunication system whereby sound and code signals are transmitted through space without wires by means of radio frequency electromagnetic waves.

Name: Durable Medical Equipment
Description: Instruments or apparatuses that aid the diagnosis, prevention, and treatment of diseases and injuries used in the practice of medicine.

Name: Cane
Description: Walking sticks, especially those with a curved handle and made of cane or bamboo.

Name: Walker
Description: Frameworks used to assist mobility for the disabled or infirm, or designed to support babies learning to walk.

Name: Scooter
Description: Foot-propelled vehicles with, usually, two wheels in tandem, a low footboard on which the rider stands set between the wheels, and a handlebar for steering, generally mounted on a vertical post; for similar, but larger and heavier, motorized vehicles, use "motor scooters."

Name: Free weights/exercise equipment
Description: Recreational Artifacts

Name: Commode
Description: Term generally applied to a variety of chairs fitted with a chamber pot. Use "bidets (box stools)" for box stools with a chamber pot.
